Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Developing Faculty Expertise in Information Assurance through Case Studies and Hands-on Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Three universities, North Carolina A & T State University, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, are collaboratively developing faculty expertise in information assurance (IA) and computer security through two faculty development workshops. Covering two years, the workshops involve thirty-six faculty members from two-year, four-year, and minority colleges and universities. The workshops are helping participants to integrate IA labs and case studies into the curricula at the participants' home institutions. The workshops are designed to increase the faculty members' expertise and their home institution's capacity to produce a diverse workforce in the area of information assurance. Personalized instruction plans and follow-up assistance are provided to faculty participants. Besides building faculty expertise, the project is improving partnerships in information assurance education.

This project is improving overall information security and critical infrastructure protection in the U.S. by producing a larger and more diverse IA workforce with better IA skills. The curriculum materials disseminated through the workshops can be adopted across multiple disciplines such as computer science, software engineering, information technology and business, and are being made available to a broader audience through conferences, publication, and a dedicated website. The project is building a community of security education experts across multiple disciplines. Broad coverage of IA topics and the introduction of innovative teaching techniques are attracting faculty participants with diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SFS Collaborative Project: Developing Faculty Expertise in Information Assurance through Case Studies and Hands-on Experiences project conducted two faculty development workshops during the summers of 2012 and 2013 to disseminate effective pedagogical practices to faculty in computer science.  The first summer workshop was held in Chattanooga, TN in May 2012 with nineteen (19) participants, and the second workshop was conducted in Greensboro, NC in May 2013 with twenty (20) participants.  The Information Assurance (IA) workshops demonstrated and taught faculty hands-on exercises and case studies for the enhancement of classroom teaching, thus improving student learning. The workshop topics cover cryptography, security ethics, security policy, digital forensics, access control, security architecture and systems, network security, risk management, attack/defense, and secure software design and engineering. The hands-on exercises and case studies disseminated through the workshops were developed in a portable manner so that they can be easily integrated into diverse disciplines including  computer science, software engineering, information technology and business. The overall project goals were to 1) build faculty capacity in information assurance education and training, 2) increase student interest and learning in information assurance, and 3) increase partnerships between institutions in information assurance education.

Faculty participant surveys, focus groups of workshop satisfaction, and long term follow up were conducted among the workshop participants by an external evaluator. Faculty workshop participants reported high levels of satisfaction with the content and tools, and knowledge gains in both 2012 and 2013 workshops. Faculty reported use of hands-on exercises and case study materials presented at the workshops in subsequently taught courses, and ease of use. Collaborations among faculty workshop participants were gained via online wiki and direct contact across participants.

 

Faculty who were teaching courses in security management, cryptography, network security, web security and access control during the term prior to their participation in the  Information Assurance Workshop were asked to invite their students to participate in a survey of interest, confidence and knowledge of those IA topics. This data served as baseline data for comparative purposes, i.e. the same faculty courses were studied following their participation in the workshop, and subsequent deployment of the case studies and hands-on tools, to see if student interest, confidence and knowledge gains were improved following implementation of the IA workshop tools. Study results showed the increase in student interest and learning in information assurance. Gains were found in student conceptual knowledge in pre/post surveys in courses implementing workshop hands-on activities and case studies. It was also found that passing grades in IA comparison courses increased after adopting the workshop methods, while failing grades decreased.

 

The thirty nine (39) workshop participants are from 37 different universities and colleges. Among them, eleven (11) are from minority institutions such as Historically Black Universities and Colleges and Hispanic Serving Institutions. Through this project, partnership was built among the project PIs from three diverse collaborative institutes, and among faculty who attended the workshops. This was evidenced by increased collaborative scholarships and proposals funded and submitted following the workshops. This project also involved students in IA research, and produced Masters projects, theses as well as publications with students as co-authors.
